reviewText:
Rza bit off more than he could chew.  This movie shouldn't have been written AND directed AND scored AND starring Rza.  However, the movie was still loads of fun and Rza has definitely proven that he has great cinematic vision.  Expect many filmmaking imperfections, but enjoy the fun ride.

Thaddeus (director Rza) is a gifted blacksmith whose talents are contracted by local warring clans.  He is pure of heart and wants nothing more than to purchase the freedom of his courtesan wife Lady Silk (Jamie Chung) from the brothel madame Blossom (Lucy Liu basically reprising her Kill Bill role).

Thaddeus becomes mixed up in a plot to steal a large shipment of gold.  The main villain is Silver Lion (Byron Mann), who betrays the Lion clan leader with the help of Bronze Lion (Cung Le; Dragon Eyes).  Zen Yi (Rick Yune; Ninja Assassin), the son of the murdered clan leader, sets out to stop Silver Lion with his armor of retractable blades.  Also in the mix is Jack Knife (Russel Crowe), the most interesting and charismatice character (outside of combat) with an interesting taste for bachelor party shenanigans (i.e., Asian call girls, liquor and opium).

The fighting in the movie was a mixed bag that will largely disappoint martial arts movie fans.  As the oddly bewigged lion clansman, Cung Le was sadly under-utilized.  He never gets to looks good or show off.  Not even in his finale fight against Lucy Liu.  The choreography presents a mix of very cool and very silly kung fu combat maneuvers.  Sadly, by and large the action is filmed way too close-up.  For me, the combat highlights should all be credited to Bautista's Brass Body.  He seemed to have the coolest scenes, obviously the coolest F/X because of his ability, and some of the most fun choreography that was filmed so that we could actually see it.

Despite my complaints about much of the action, the kung fu theater feel was maintained undeniably well.  Rza captured that tone perfectly.  There was also a festive display of spewy-fun gore.

The dialogue is dreadfully dry (except for Crowe's delivery).  Rza, God bless him for trying, can't act or effectively narrate.  His character was not only understated, but lacked the lines to justify his purpose.  It seems that Rza was going for a mood-driven film with stylized combat like Bunraku or The Warrior's Way.  I could see his goal, but his meant-to-be-poetic blacksmith character was clearly the weak link in synthesizing this quasi-arthouse-ful conceptual grace.  Rza tries to use a Shaolin Temple training flashback to corroborate Thaddeus' focus and combat ability.  Still, I found him to have zero combat credibility when facing Iron Body--a character who actually earned my respect on screen.

The score (also by Rza) was cool during the first scene (a fight scene).  But I noticed less effective use of music later in the movie.  I'm not hating, it was a neat score.  But this was disappointing as I expected to have some awesomely rap-scored fight scenes, but some of them had combat volume drowning out the music, rendering it ineffective even at times that louder music would be appropriate.

Director Rza--of the Wu Tang Clan--was always a devout fan of Hong Kong cinema's kung fu theater.  While his direction is clearly fledgling and his scoring ability nothing to his own rapping talent, his passion for classic kung fu movies manifested the greatest strength of this film: the kung fu theater "feel" of it all.  His excellent theatrical homage includes some classic kung fu movie components such as the iron body (brass body in the movie) focus style, techniques that are named after characters (e.g., the Gemini stance), the betrayal of one's master and the revenge that follows, the house of mirrors fight (which was unfortunately brief), traps and poison darts, fighters exploding from the ground in ambush and semi-flying combat maneuvers.  Perhaps the most fun was when all of the brothel whores turn out to be ninja-savvy combat-chic assassins.  Rza also covered the bases of kung fu weaponry, including bladed fans, bladed sleeve extensions, chain-fighting, various blades and good-old kung fu.

This movie shouldn't have been written AND directed AND scored AND starring Rza.  However, the movie was still loads of fun and Rza has definitely proven that he has great cinematic vision.  I'd like to see him collaborate with more experienced film makers before attempting another solo venture like this.  But I am so glad that I got to see it anyway, imperfections and all.  This was a good debut considering his complete lack of experience since yet more experienced hands have failed to produce such entertainment time and time again.

RZA waited a long time to tell this story, this brainchild of his, inspired by untold hours of viewing kung-fu flicks during his formative years. The Shaw Brothers as baby sitters? Sure, why not. RZA grew up sort of a historian on kung fu pictures, this guy from Brooklyn who can go toe to toe, trivia for trivia, with Hong Kong action cinema experts like Bey Logan. And how does RZA's THE MAN WITH THE IRON FISTS stack up against classics like THE 36TH CHAMBER OF SHAOLIN, MAD MONKEY KUNG FU, and THE FIVE DEADLY VENOMS?

Okay, THE MAN WITH THE IRON FISTS isn't the best martial arts film released stateside this year (That would be Iko Uwais's THE RAID: REDEMPTION). Whereas THE RAID: REDEMPTION grounded itself in vicious but realistic combat sequences, RZA's pet project is more steeped in the bizarre and the fanciful. A mythical element creeps in. In RZA's personal vision of wuxia, a fighter's flesh can transmutate into metal. A laborer, by dint of will power, can animate his prostheses. It's a fun show.

In the 19th century, the freed slave Thaddeus Henry Smith (RZA) made his way to feudal China, and in the tiny Jungle Village has made a home. Thaddeus is a gifted blacksmith, a peaceful, quiet man. Except that the rough characters in Jungle Village frequently contract his metal-shaping services. And so the blacksmith reluctantly perverts the lessons he'd learned, and he forges jagged weapons of mayhem. Thaddeus's only haven lies in the arms of Lady Silk (Jamie Chung), a courtesan in the local brothel. He dreams of earning enough gold to buy out Lady Silk's contract from the brothel's madame (Lucy Liu). Then they'd go away together. So he keeps on making killing weapons. He turns a blind eye to his conscience.

RZA's blacksmith is only one character in a plot that revolves around the Governor's gold shipment, and how all manner of hooligans go all out to obtain it. The central villain is the duplicitous Silver Lion (Byron Mann) of the Lion clan, him what just ruthlessly betrayed his leader, Gold Lion. Fast approaching is Zen Yi (Rick Yune), revenge-inclined son of Gold Lion and wearer of a suit of nasty blades. Today Silver Lion and his minions ride roughshod over Jungle Village. And is it a coincidence that Jungle Village is one of the stops in the gold shipment's itinerary? Does a bear crap in the woods? Is RZA fond of letters in caps?

I admire RZA's efforts. Dude's a quadruple threat: he wrote, scored, directed, and acted in this movie. Those into martial arts movies may be aware of RZA's rep as a hardcore addict of kung fu cinema. RZA's been known to drop an audio commentary or two for past DVD releases (like THE 36TH CHAMBER OF SHAOLIN). Don't be surprised when RZA manages to rep the Shaolin Temple in a flashback sequence. Me, I enjoyed THE MAN WITH THE IRON FISTS. I wish that RZA hadn't been so understated in his performance. As the prohibitive protagonist, the sleepy-eyed RZA needed to generate more energy, more life. Thankfully, Russell Crowe picks up the slack, provides the swagger and the big personality as the enigmatic (and amusingly lecherous) Englishman, Jack (or "Mr. Knife"). Jack Knife is shady, his motivations murky. All we know is that he loves women and that he always brings a gun to a knife fight. You're kept guessing until the third act just which side he'll fall on. THE MAN WITH THE IRON FISTS is packed with amped-up wire-fu theatrics. The violence is brutal but so exaggerated it achieves an almost cartoonish vibe. Set your eyeballs on alert for cameos by Pam Grier and Hong Kong legend Gordon Liu. MMA fighter Cung Le has a supporting bit as Bronze Lion. As a bonus for the theater goer, THE MAN WITH THE IRON FISTS is presented by an onscreen Quentin Tarantino, after which he introduces a trailer for his upcoming DJANGO UNCHAINED.

This is a flick that Joe Bob Briggs would love. While deficient in motor vehicle chases (no motor vehicles), no beasts (but some pretty beastly Chinese gangsters) and only two (ceramic) breasts, The Man with the Iron Fists is an excellent chop socky movie. We have spinning assassin bimbo fu, truly overwhelming Chinese Whore-Lady fu with a cast of dozens of flying Beautiful Chinese Ninja Whore-Ladies, a ex-slave Hero (RZA) who trades in his `fro for `fu training at the same Shaolin temple that trained John Carradine, a baddy (Dave Bautista)that turns into a brass table lamp every time someone tries to stick him (which happens a lot) and lots and _lots_ of straight and fancy kung fu. In a movie first, Russell Crowe performs Ben Wa Ball fu on one of the Chinese Whore-Ladies.
We have heads rolling, eyes rolling, hands rolling and stomachs rolling. We have a baddie dragged into the gears for a really messy exit, Squirt! At the other end of the ceramic breasts, is the lock to the Secret Tunnel (tm) and the Head Whore-Lady (Lucy Lui) thrusts a foot-long key straight in there to unlock the Hidden Door.
The scenery-chewing was awesome, especially Russell Crowe's Chinese "disguise" (coolie hat, slanty-eyed mascara). The score is excellent and subtle, bringing in references to other Manly Movies. Several times, I expected Lee Van Cleef and Clint Eastwood to stride in from stage right and left respectively.
Five Stars: Check it out.

I have always been a huge fan of the Kiwi actor, Russell Crowe, ever since he, back in 2005, confronted the American singer called Moby in a bathroom and a/s/sailed him with a bunch of anti-American slurs. I think that alone qualifies Crowe as the greatest actor the world has ever seen...if you do not count Carrot Top, Pauly Shore and Tom Green, of course! I'm glad to see him back in this martial arts movie conceived of by none other than RZA, who is a rapper from the Wu-Tang Clan and a 110 percent, hardcore Obama voter, to be sure.

This highly poetic movie that is best enjoyed like you would a fine glass of wine centers around RZA, a blacksmith, who fashions highly complex weapons of destruction for a small village located inside of Chinatown. After a person who is planning to commit treason (also known as a traitor) menaces the village, the blacksmith teams up with both good guys and bad guys to defend the community of wonton soup-enjoyers. As you can see from this plot description alone, this movie will likely be the movie nominated for the most Oscars, on account of its extreme, arthouse quality and attention to method acting.

Since this is a martial arts movie, I was not at all surprised to see Carl Douglas make several cameos while singing Kung F/u Fighting, which was easily...easily the sole highlight of this entire train-wreck of a film. I am, nonetheless, a little bit worried about the implied racism with his cameos because they are essentially a black man singing about Asian people in Kung F/u Fighting, which means two minority groups are mercilessly referenced...true racism if I ever saw it! However, a small upside was the brilliant and inspired casting of Dave "The Manimal" Bautista as one of the rice-eating villagers in this funky tale. I was especially impressed with him powerbombing, bodyslamming and spinebusting Russell Crowe and the rapper from Wu-Tang Clan several times over. That is surely powerful filmmaking at its most awesomest.

I am going to go out on a small limb here and make a prediction: The Man with the Iron Fists will easily sashay away with the Best Picture Oscar in 2013. You heard it here from me first, people. Just remember that when all those a-h/o/l/e/s at Entertainment Tonight are taking credit for making this prediction when Oscar season rolls around, okay? Sup.

the only thing i knew about rza before i saw this movie was that he appeared in the movie "the protector 2," which was unbelievably awful, although to be fair, he wasn't the worst part of it.  when i saw that he not only starred but also directed this one, i thought "man, this movie is going to be a trainwreck."  but imagine my surprise when it was actually pretty dang entertaining.  it's fast-paced and outrageous, with great set design, interesting characters, and crazy fight scenes that suffer only a little bit from obvious wire-work.  the plot is reasonably complex with lots of characters sneaking around, and you aren't really sure where their loyalties lie.

in "the man with the iron fists," however, rza is the weakest point as far as acting is concerned.  he's not bad, exactly, but he plays the role so laid-back and calm that he's kind of boring.  in some scenes it looks like he's about to fall asleep.  thankfully, he's surrounded by lots of other actors so he doesn't have to carry the entire film.  to contrast rza's sleepy performance, we have russell crowe going all-out as a british special agent in one of his silliest and most entertaining performances, and byron long as a flamboyant gang leader with hair straight out of a 1980s hard rock video.

in general, i liked it a lot, but the pacing was little bit off, rza's acting leaves much to be desired, and the flashback scenes about his character seem totally out of place.  but the direction, the set design, and the fight scenes are all great.

I'm not shocked to find bad reviews here - don't go into this expecting a typical king fu movie and don't go into it expecting a Quentin Terentino flick. Go into it expecting a badass fantasy kung fu movie by hip hop legend. Because that's what it is.
For years RZA has been crossbreeding elements of classic kung fu movies and urban culture to create music - from his productions for the Wu Tang Clan to numerous movie soundtracks and even anime (Afrosamurai).  Naturally his film - making debut does the same!
It's campy at times, but quite intentionally.  It's fantasy, but it's supposed to be - and results in some new ideas and unique designs.  Solid cast who know action and kung fu.  It has an excellent mold of hip hop and eastern orchestra soundtrack - sone reviewers seem to hate it but for me that was absolutely the best part!
To be honest, as a fan of his music, it was pretty much everything i was hoping it would be.  Is it a movie only RZA fans will enjoy? Maybe? I don't know, but if you aren't a fan of the RZA but DO enjoy this movie then you should probably look into his other work!

Okay.  I can see Cung Le, Rick Yune, Byron Mann, and Dave Bautista in an over-the-top throwback to 1970s grindhouse martial arts movie like this, aided and (woefully) abetted by the ridiculous blood and gore quotient that torture porn director Eli Roth brings to the screen.  I can especially see Wu Tang Clan's RZA (such a truly horrible actor who talks like he's got rocks in his mouth) in a movie like this (he's the director) given that musical group's well-documented love of the martial arts genre (among other things).  I can eve see Lucy Liu putting her tongue-in-cheek two cents into this as well given her pedigree of movies like "Charlie's Angels" and "Kill Bill".  But Russell Crowe?  How'd they get him in here?!?  This movie's bad enough to make you think that he can't act!  He certainly phones it in as Jack Knife, bringing a (significantly altered) spaghetti western feel to this piece of crass Americanized oriental cinema.

This swing-and-a-miss bit of kung fu fantasy shows a lot of flare and pizzazz with bright colors and well thought and constructed/ structured set pieces but misses its target by a lot in its over-reliance on gore and special effects to make up for lackluster and obviously derivative fight sequences (and derivative isn't nearly a bad thing often if it's done well and tweaks or juices the formula just a bit) like Zen Yi and Silver Lion's mirrored maze showdown.  [This is all the more surprising and dismaying seeing that famed martial arts fight choreographer choreographed these fights!]  And that's too bad because it shows promise at times and who's making movies like this nowadays for fans of this genre?

I applaud RZA for making this movie but hopefully some of his friends will be in his ear the next time advising him to let more competent actors do the acting (and fighting), rely less on the spfx budget, and tighten up the action (the script, while no great thing, was fine for this film).  Sure, make it fantastical, but reference classics like "Duel to the Death" to see what this could have really been like.  And there's an idea: remake "Duel to the Death" (but for viewers' sake stick close to the original)!

RZA's lavish vanity project (filmed in China) is a stylistic mess. "The Man with the Iron Fists" might have fared better if the Wu-Tang Clan leader stayed behind the camera. Russell Crowe and Lucy Liu are worth watching in this sluggish martial-arts epic with an incongruous hip-hop soundtrack. Not a total disaster, but disappointing for a Quentin Tarantino "presentation."

Even though there are hundreds of reviews of this movie I decided to also write one. I just picked up this DVD (The Man with the Iron Fists-Unrated extended edition) a week ago and viewed it a few days ago.  This is a Quentin Tarantino presents movie so I knew there would be plenty of action.  I was not disappointed.  This classic martial arts film has some fantastic fight scenes and stars Russell Crowe and Lucy Liu, as well as some other well-known martial arts stars.

Like many movies of this genre it is sometimes confusing as to who the good guys are and who the bad guys are; nevertheless, by the time it ends it is clear who the bad guys are because they are all dead.  There are also quite a few sex scenes which make this an R rated DVD.  This extended version also has scenes that were not in the theater movie.

One of the ways I judge whether a movie deserves a high rating or a low one, is if I would enjoy seeing the movie more than once.  Without a doubt, I will watch this DVD again and again in the future.

If you are into fast paced martial arts action films you should check out this one. You can pick it up for a bargain on Amazon as well as some bargain stores.

Rza would have been better off getting the film properly scored instead of creating a Rap soundtrack for the background music. It was very distracting.

Second, Rza choosing to have an African American character in the film, working as a blacksmith, might have worked. The only problem is, he chose to play the role himself. I have to agree with what others have already stated. Rza is not a very good actor in general. Add to that his street flare as he delivers his lines, and you have a mismatch character who doesn't really belong in the story. As a result, It was difficult to buy into his role. Had he picked a seasoned actor instead, it might have worked out. But as is, this film was likely a life long dream of his, so I guess he had to fit himself in somewhere. In retrospect, it was a mistake.

I commend him, however, for tapping into the Asian American acting pool for his lead roles. Lucy Lui did well enough, as did Ricky Yune. Jamie Chung also appears in the film as Rza's love interest, but she doesn't really get enough screen time to leave her mark. It seemed like she was mainly there to give Rza's character a connection to the film. Russell Crowe also  appears  and his acting is always good. But in this case,  he seemed out of place. His character was odd and seemed to be written in just to have an excuse for more star power on the screen. At least, that's the way it seemed to me.

The martial arts were OK, but they don't hold a flame to the HK classics from the 70's and 80's. My advice is, if you want a good Kung Fu flick, just go to the source. Either check out some Shaw Brother's films or look for some filmed  by Golden Harvest Pictures. They have real Kung Fu stories that work while showcasing excellent Kung Fu. Rza's  version is more of a Kung Fu parody that pays homage to the genre, but doesn't really hit the mark.

In the end I gave the film 2 stars. Rza did manage to insert some of the  ideas you expect in a Kung Fu flick. He also enlisted the aide of  Asian American actors, so he gets another star for that. But overall, this is not a great film. It's just too far out of the norm to be a good Kung Fu flick. All you're left with while watching this film is a lingering hope that it might improve. But unfortunately, it never does. Definitely a one time rental at best.

Man, where to begin?  Firstly, I am a life-long fan of martial arts films.  Everything from Kurosawa's 1943 (Judo vs Jujitsu) classic "Sanshiro Sugata", to the modern gore & brutality of 2011's "The Raid", and just about everything in between.  I fell in love with film fighting during the '80s, when I was allowed to stay up late to watch "Kung Fu Theater", featuring traditional Chinese fighting styles and costumes.  My discovery was probably not too long after the film's 1st time writer/director, RZA, began his own obsession with this particular brand of escapism.  When I first heard that RZA was writing and directing a kung fu movie, I could barely contain my excitement.  A while later, when I finally saw the first trailer for it, I could hardly contain my contempt.  It looked awful.  After unfavorable reviews started pouring in, I thought it best to cut my losses and avoid seeing it at all.  Many months passed until just last week, when it was available for checkout from my local library.  A trusted source's recent reserved recommendation sealed the deal.  I lowered my expectations and had a go.  I gotta say, there was some pretty cool stuff going on here.  Was it still disappointing?  Yes, but if I came away with anything, it's a sincere hope that RZA continues in this profession.  My man leapt right into the 35th Chamber of filmmaking, and while not graduating, I think he showed the monks he means business.

In Jungle Village (kind of a late-1800s, Chinese version of Mos Eisley from "Star Wars"), powerful clans converge to steal a large portion of gold that will be escorted through town via the governor's order.  Knowing of the cutthroats that reside there, the governor has requested the extra security of the Lion clan.  The clan's leader, Gold Lion (Chen Kwan Tai, "Dragon Tiger Gate") agrees until his lieutenants, Silver (Byron Mann, "Belly of the Beast") & Bronze (Cung Le, "Dragon Eyes") betray and murder him.  Seems they want the gold for themselves.  Not taking the other clans too seriously, it seems the only real threat to their plan is Gold's son, Zen Yi, aka the X-Blade (Rick Yune, "Ninja Assassin"), and eventually Thaddeus (RZA, "Coffee & Cigarettes"), the town's blacksmith, whose business is booming with weapon requests for the impending rumble.  There are many other characters, including Russell Crowe  ("L.A. Confidential") as the Englishman, Jack Knife, and Lucy Liu ("Kill Bill") as the owner of the local brothel that EVERYONE frequents.

I refuse to call out RZA for plagiarism because these types of films borrowed from one another quite liberally and I recognized most of his source material.  The majority of this picture was borrowed from "The Kid With The Golden Arm" (1979), "Flag of Iron" (aka "Spearman", 1980), and "Crippled Avengers" (1978): movies starring the group of 6 actors known as the Venom mob (from their most popular film together, "5 Deadly Venoms"), who worked for the Shaw Brothers studio in the mid-to-late '70s, specifically for the late director Chang Cheh ("One Armed Swordsman").  Elements are also borrowed from other Shaw flicks, like "Cave of the Silken Web" (1967) and "The 36th Chamber of Shaolin" (1978).

The fight scenes?  It saddens me to report that, well, frankly, they suck.  The bullseye (or at least its periphery) of RZA's target audience is more-or-less me and had the kung fu been good I would've been absolutely enamored with this film.  Dreadful use of wires, editing, CGI gore, and slow motion totally sink the action.  RZA and co-writer Eli Roth ("Hostel") developed original weapons for the film and they're pretty sweet.  If only they had figured out a way to shoot the scenes where these items were utilized.  Rick Yune, Cung Le, and WWE/MMA fighter Dave Bautista (as Brass Body) are really the only ones that get to show off any good moves but they're still disappointing due to poor handling.

The Universal DVD contains both R-rated and Unrated versions, coming in at 96 & 108 minutes, respectively.  The image is colorful and splendid with a nice 2.40:1 widescreen picture.  Spoken languages are available in English, Spanish, and French, with subtitles in English or French.  Special features include: deleted scenes, "A Look Inside...", "Path To The East", and "On The Set With RZA".  I really can't recommend this as a martial arts film but I can as a slice of kung fu nostalgia for old-school fans. One man's opinion - Let me start by saying I watch movies... a LOT of movies.  On a given week I can easily view 15-20 movies - being permanently disabled has given me a lot of time on my hands.  Secondly, I LOVE BAD MOVIES... not all bad movies, but generally speaking the cheesier the better.  I love it when a bad movie crosses that invisible line between simply terrible to a new paradigm - what I like to call "So bad, it's good".  Need an example, "Battle Beyond the Stars" or as I like to call it John Boy in Space!!!  It's terrible, it's wonderfully, joyfully, nay, tearfully terrible.  Watch virtually ANY Christopher Lee horror film from the 60s or 70s.  You probably get the picture so I'll move on.  I bought this supposedly "Tarantino" film expecting bad - I wasn't disappointed (in that).

It really didn't take very long to realize the only thing Quentin Tarantino had to do with this film was to make money off his name.  The filming of this movie had nothing of his quirkiness or well thought out scenes, none of his witty script-craft, and none of his skill in bringing a film to the silver screen.  What does appear on screen is a movie, poorly shot, poorly acted, poorly scripted, poorly organized, poorly scored.  The "short of it" in Texas parlance can be summed up thus - a hot mess, bless their hearts.

How could this huge mistake have happened you might ask yourself (I sure did).  When a film goes this far off the ranch you have to start with the basics - who wrote the film - they are ultimately responsible for what's presented.  The film was written by Robert Diggs (East Coast Rapper and Wu-Tang Clan leader) and Eli Roth (of 'Hostel' and 'Hostel:Part 2' fame (ya, I missed those two too)).  The film was directed by Diggs... and stars Diggs as well (or as he self-styled RZA - a moniker which in this movie's case should stand for Razzle (Dazzle) since the film has so little substance and so much flash).  Mr. Razzle Dazzle also was responsible for the soundtrack (I know, big surprise there too).  RZA was clearly over his head in every way imaginable, the writing is sluggish and uninspired, the directing is amateurish, the soundtrack commits the ultimate sin - its so poorly married to what's happening on screen it pulls you out of the movie, and the acting was flat.  I can almost forgive RZA for his performance and ever-present hip-hop / hood-inspired language (what direction is 'Norf' anyway?  That's right, I'm 'axing' you), but the deplorable job done by both once A-List stars Russell Crowe and Lucy Liu leaves much to the imagination (and what you fill in for their apparent lack of enthusiasm wasn't good).  Crowe would seem to be going the way of Marlon Brando (all the girth and half the talent) and Liu's performance is a text book example of how she has gone from Lucy Liu to Lucy Who?  If I could give the film no stars I would.  It's not worth the cardboard it came wrapped in.  I hope Tarantino enjoyed the cash given to borrow his name and I sincerely hope he actually reads the next script before cashing the check - in this business we call show, reputation is everything and this was most certainly NOT a Tarantino film.  One or two of these and his fan base will take a walk (I hope your listening Mr. Tarantino, I'm still a fan... for now).  In summary - Hot Mess, RZA=Razzle Dazzle, Lucy Who? and DON'T BUY THIS FILM, DON'T EVEN RENT IT - just walk away... run if you're able.

As the first mainstream American kung fu movie to be produced in about ten years, I promised myself to see it. I wasn't sure what to make of its first-time director, but by and large I was excited for it. However, I ended up not getting to see the picture until recently, and by then, some trepidation had built up for me, based on the lukewarm reviews I had come across. I'm glad for them, because this would have been a pretty big letdown otherwise. "The Man with the Iron Fists" is an entertaining action flick and certainly not bad, but stylistic choices by the filmmakers hinder what could have been a very good adventure and dilute it to mere little more than a visually interesting time-killer. The story: an assortment of warriors, assassins, and various deadly individuals - all in pursuit of treasure - descend on a small town overseen by a unique blacksmith (director and rap star Robert "RZA" Diggs)... Director and leading man RZA is a hardcore fan of traditional kung fu flicks, and producer-in-spirit Quentin Tarantino is big on retro repackages. They have fine ideologies, but I'm fairly certain that the movie could have been made without being so ridiculously hokey. The cheesy opening titles, the recycled Shaw Bros. sound effects, the cartoon gore, and a good deal of the dialogue are constant reminders that the filmmakers didn't take their product very seriously, and I'm a bit resentful for it. Not only does this seem to act as a waiver for any technical shortcomings (see the unrated version, mainly), but all of this had already been done better a decade ago with Tarantino's own Kill Bill. Guys, it's *okay* to fill a movie full of cool things; you don't have to account or apologize for it with comedy. And there certainly is a good deal of cool things to be found here. Artistically, the movie is a success, with great sets and unique costumes. Many of the special weapons I had never seen before. The storyline is juicy, and it moves at a swift comic book pace that I find appealing. And the casting is, for the most part, full of winners. Rick Yune (Ninja Assassin) as a main hero, Lucy Liu as the deadly madam of a brothel, and ex-WWE star Dave Bautista as a monstrous enforcer - good. Byron Mann (Street Fighter) as the lead villain, Kwan Tai-Chen (The 5 Deadly Venoms) as his ill-fated father, and MMA champ Cung Le as the former's main henchman - very good. David Wu (Legend of the Black Scorpion) as a creepy assassin and the singular Gordon Liu as the teacher of RZA's character - fantastic. RZA himself gives a much better performance than expected. I have no idea what Kurt Russell is doing in this movie, but in the end, his performance as the horny gunslinger is endearing. Of course, the best action cast in the world is only as good as its action scenes, and disappointingly, I think these fights could have been better. They could have been a lot worse, of course, but considering the amount of talent involved and that they're wrangled by Corey Yuen - one of my favorite action coordinators - they definitely fall short of their potential. There isn't a single fight scene that I can point to as an example of a great cinematic brawl. Part of this is due to the style in which they're choreographed; I'm not a huge fan of wire-fu. Nevertheless, the wirework shows some ingenuity (e.g. the Gemini fight), and in the end, the biggest drawbacks of the brawls are that too few of them feature any amount of satisfying back & forth action and that too many of them feature an overabundance of slow motion and CGI enhancements. These are clearly supposed to be Hong Kong-styled fights, but come off more as Americanized Hong Kong knockoffs. With that said, there are several good (not great) fights, among them the showdown between RZA and Bautista's characters, which is better than it has any right to be in my opinion. I think that's the best way to approach this movie - with low expectations, so that you're pleasantly surprised at the highlights and not too disappointed by the shortcomings. For his junior outing as both an actor and a director, RZA does a good job, but I think he was held back by both the ambitiousness of this project and the influence of the folks who were supporting him (read: writer-producer Eli Roth). I'd be interested in watching the sequel that's set up during the credits, but that one will have a lot it needs to build on if it's going to be better than this.

In my opinion The Man With The Iron Fists is kind of a mixed bag. It's easy to fall in love with because it's obviously supposed to be over-the-top and cheesy, but at the same time nothing really feels memorable. To be honest I don't think I've actually seen a kung-fu movie so this is probably my first, but upon doing some research apparently what we see in The Man With The Iron Fists is pretty standard as far as martial arts films go.

The story is a little difficult to explain due to the fact that it lacks any sense of direction. Basically we start off with the leader of the Lion clan, Gold Lion, getting assassinated. This leaves his two subordinates, Silver Lion (Byron Mann) and Bronze Lion (Cung Le), to take his place as leaders of the clan. Gold Lion was a leader who believed in peace while Silver Lion has a lust for war. In an effort to eliminate all traces of Gold Lion, he sends assassins to eliminate Gold Lion's only son, Zen-Yi aka The X-Blade (Rick Yune).

After word got out that Gold Lion was assassinated, a mysterious man by the name of Jack Knife (Russell Crowe) arrives at Jungle Village. The viewer doesn't learn who he is or why he's there until the final 30 minutes or so. Until then he's staying at The Pink Blossom, a brothel run by Madam Blossom (Lucy Liu). Jack is probably one of my favorite characters because of his personality. He gives off this very calm, cool, collective vibe that Crowe does a wonderful job of pulling off. He's here for business and he doesn't have time to waste.

My main reason for seeing this was RZA. Up until now he's appeared in some small roles here and there, but The Man With The Iron Fist is the first time he's getting the chance to play a major character. RZA plays an unnamed blacksmith who makes weapons for the rival clans. He's not on any specific side, he's just trying to save up enough money so he can leave Jungle Village with Lady Silk (Jamie Chung), his girlfriend and a prostitute at the Pink Blossom. I think the goal was to make this blacksmith the main character, but any effort to pull that off was eliminated when he's absent for majority of the first half.

I think that's where I kind of got turned off. I enjoy films that follow a specific character/set of characters throughout the entire film. The Man With The Iron Fists is one of those films that jumps back and forth between multiple people. You have Silver Lion, Jack Knife, Madam Blossom, Brass Body (Dave Batista), and the blacksmith. Because there's so many key characters it's hard to form any sort of connection with any of them. That's not to say that they're all empty shells. On the contrary, I already mentioned my love for Jack, but Madam Blossom proves to be a pretty badass character and Brass Body (cheesy name aside) is interesting as well. The thing is that they only get brief spurts of screen time here and there which makes it hard to really care.

My biggest issues, however, were the special effects and the predictability of the story. There's a scene within the first five minutes where a man is being attacked by a pack of wolves against what appears to be a barn door. It's obvious that these "wolves" are as fake as they come. In fact, these effects are so bad that when it cuts to this scene the color scheme changes from dark and solid to light and washed out. Then the fake blood used throughout the movie is just awful. There's been movies where the fake blood looks like fake blood, but this didn't even resemble blood at all. Whenever there was a spurt of blood erupting from a mouth, stab wound, etc. it looked like cherry soda. Part of me feels that this was intentional just to add to the cheesiness, but either way it just didn't do it for me.

Then there was the story. Don't get me wrong, there were some things that I wasn't expecting, but majority of the time I said "This is probably going to happen." and sure enough it did. For example, there was a scene where the Lions stayed at The Pink Blossom and the women were ordered to "entertain" them. Right away I said "Lady Silk is going to get Brass Body". You wanna know what happened? Brass Body came into her room and wound up beating her to a pulp. I mean I understand that this is normal to include things like this because we've seen it done so many times in the past, but don't you think it's time that someone breaks the cycle?

What really drives this film though is the performances from the cast members. It's clear that RZA is still a developing actor so don't expect some breathtaking performance, but considering that this is his first major role he did a solid job. Russell Crowe gave a great performance as Jack which more than makes up for his lackluster effort in Broken City. Rick Yune and Lucy Lui gave great performances as well, as did David Bautista, Byron Mann, and Jamie Chung. A lot of great performances from a pretty well-rounded cast.

Overall Score: 6/10 - To be totally honest I expected more from The Man With The Iron Fists. From start to finish it felt really cluttered and directionless and the ending felt sudden and underwhelming. If you're a fan of kung-fu movies and you know what to expect then it would be very easy for me to recommend this to you. For everyone else I would advise you to go in with an open mind. While I personally can't say that I'll ever watch this again, I don't regret taking the time to experience it because when it's all said and done it was a nice ride.

Rapper and wannabe actor RZA also directs and contributed to the screenplay (with Eli Roth) in this Tarantino endorsed throwback to `70's kung fooey movies.  RZA plays an under-the-radar metal smith in a Chinese province circa 1870.  He had escaped slavery with the help of his mother (Pam Grier) and hopped on a boat for China.  It sunk with everyone on board drowned but for Blacksmith as he is known.

His main job is to fabricate the unusual armament for the local thugs.  In a thin plot, a shipment of gold is being transported to the governor over land, protected by a top notch group of guardians.  Also interested in the gold is a mysterious caucasian named Jack Knife (a portly Russell Crowe) and the owner of the high end brothel, Madam Blossom (Lucy Liu).  Rick Yune plays one of the good guys known as The X-Blade because of his ability to fling various sharp instruments at his adversaries.  He's headed to the village as well to avenge his father's death at the hand of the aforementioned thugs.

Numerous battles take place always involving magical feats of jumping and suspension in midair.  Some of the weapons are admittedly pretty cool, but much of the action sequences are nothing special in this day and age of photo trickery.  Perhaps the most memorable sequences are the massive amounts of blood spurting during the fight scenes.

First off, let me begin by saying that Rza did an ok job with what he had.  For a guy who had not directed a decent budget film, this was alright.  Now to break it down.

The basis of the story was there.  We had the feud between clans, the emperors gold that they were after, and your quiet hero (the blacksmith).  He developed the relationship between the blacksmith and the prostitute fairly well but there was nothing about how they met.  How could a blacksmith win the heart of the prostitute with a heart of gold when she is kept in the brothel all the time?  ALso, what is the origin of the bronze man?  We have no idea why he had Marvel hero like powers where his body can change to bronze when attacked.  In addition, Rza's narration was, most of the time, too low to hear and when we could hear, it was difficult to understand him at times.  Even during the film, his lines were muffled almost beyond recognition.  I had to rewind it to try to understand what he was saying.  Next time, get someone who has a background in narration that can portray your sentiment as the central character.

One small gripe I had is that it seemed like the times were not consistent.  At some points it looked as if this movie was set in the 1800s in the midst of slavery and some times it seemed like it could have been in the early 1900s (wardrobe, weapons, etc.)  I was confused at some points.

Continuing on, there was too much filler in this movie.  At some points there were just meaningless scenes that felt like music videos.  For example, there was about a 1-2 minute scene of the women in the brothel bathing themselves with no dialogue or anything.  It wasn't a segway, it was just a meaningless waste of film that had no bearing on the rest of the film.

In addition, the gore was way overdone.  You should not hear the sounds of the blood packs squirting out as the character removes the knife from your neck.  It seemed cheesy and just overly dramatic.  A continuation of this, make your effects consistent.  If you use CGI for your gore and blood spatter, use that throughout the film. Don't use blood packs for some fight scenes and CGI blood splatter for another, it makes for choppy non-uniform production.  At least Tarantino uses blood like substances throughout and keeps his films consistent.

So while my review is all over the place, I will sum up quickly.  While this film is not bad, it is not great either.  It sits quietly in the middle with its perks and its shortcomings.  I would like to see Rza refine his craft and give it another go, but the film just needs to be more comfortable with itself and not trying to live up to the name of its producer.  Rza has a nice vision of film and his story was there, but it just didn't develop completely for me.

The man with the iron fists attempts to pay tribute to all those old Kung Fu movies that were popular in the 70's. Iron Fists' bloody and hyper real opening title sequence is perhaps the best evidence of what RZA had in mind when he started developing his love letter to East Asian cinema, and there's no denying the film's clever use of wirework and sublime imagery to sell that notion. The production's use of authentic Chinese locations also offers a sense of visual grandeur.

Where Iron Fists falls apart is in its contrived mythology. While it's obvious that RZA and co-writer Eli Roth spent a lot of time developing this complex universe filled with
warring clans, mystic ideologies and thorough backstories, none of those ever become fully realized over the course of the movie, even with the Unrated Edition's extended runtime. Instead of a restrained, balanced narrative, the director spends more time cramming in as many tributes to past works as he can, without establishing his own unique style. As a result, Iron Fists becomes less of a modern spin on a classic genre and more of a muddy, bombastic tribute video.
That's not to say the film isn't without SOME  entertainment value. Iron Fists' over-the-top fight sequences are among some of its strongest moments, and the choreography is, on the whole, impressive. Admittedly, RZA is probably the weakest link in terms of both fighting and acting. However, martial artists Rick Yune, Byron Mann and Cung Le add some credibility to the choreo, and Russell Crowe turns out a fun performance as the gunblade-slinger Jack Knife.

It's just a shame none of these elements form any  kind of cohesive whole.

I must preface by saying that I like Kung Fu movies -- and I've seen my share of them. The Man with the Iron Fists has the body of a new style Chinese Martial Arts film like House of the Flying Daggers, the brains of Enter the Dragon, and the soul of Machete -- although it's not nearly as much fun as Robert Rodriquez's similar riff on the Mexican Gangster film. Fists isn't really a Chinese film at all, although plenty of the talent is from the Middle Kingdom, but instead is a re-envisioned fantasy of the Kung Fu genre through the eyes of Wu-Tang mastermind and rapper RZA. He wrote, directed, and starred.

There's a lot to like in this film (as a Kung Fu fan). The characters are pretty memorable in a comic book, kung fu, video game kind of way. They each have their own weapons, powers, and gimmicks. A few of them are even well acted (or over acted) like Russell Crowe's entertaining performance as Jack Knife or Lucy Liu as Black Widow. Many have bad hair.

RZA and his titular character forms the weakest link. He's just flat. His voice over is hard to understand and the rapper voice narrating Kung Fu feels totally out of place. But his music's good. And despite some nearly incoherent editing and minimal storytelling, the overall style is pretty decent.

The villains are pretty darn cheesy, particularly the heavy metal fright wig hair styles of the Lion Clan, but whatever, it's a campy almost spoof of the Kung Fu genre. It's gory as hell too, but despite numerous brothel scenes, strangely chaste (no nudity at all). Hmmm, there's that weird violence is better than sex thing. What gives? A big chunk of backstory on RZA's character shoved into the middle of the film is a total snooze-a-rama, but other than  that, the action scenes are exciting and the brothel scenes funny, so if you like the genre, go for it. Just remember, it's just no Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon and not even up to the standards of Kung Fu Hustle.

Andy Gavin, author of The Darkening Dream and Untimed

Acting: This is probably one of the strong points in the film. Lucy Liu and Russell Crowe are both entertaining, even if Crowe is larger than life and his character is one of the awkward points in the story. RZA isn't terrible at acting in this film, but he seems like he doesn't fit well into his character's skin and it was very evident. He seems to have a half asleep expression throughout the film that's distracting and actually takes a lot away from his character.

Style and Visual Effects: You'll know 5 minutes into this film if this is something that you are interested in. The "kung fu" is exaggerated and about as far as you can get from what it would look like/be possible in real life - many punches never connect and many enemies go flying due to said punches. It is similar to kung fu hustle/warrior's way style, but taken another step in the direction of unbelievable.

Music: This was actually a strong point in this film. If nothing else if you know RZA's style and you enjoy the music then you'll like this soundtrack.

Overall: Entertaining, but I wouldn't watch it again. I feel like there was a lot of potential and talent in this film that wasn't tapped. RZA needs a more simple (it could have been very simple) story line to direct. He attempted to create a film that would surprise and awe the audience. Instead, he created a film that baffled and confused most viewers. 2. The acting is just as bad.  The only saving grace is watching Byron Mann (Ryu from the first Street Fighter movie) play a ridiculous character.  To be fair, Russell Crowe and Rick Yune seemed to do their best at trying to save bad roles.
3. The music selection is distracting.  Choosing to play nearly incoherent rap over unexplained scenes that supposedly impact the story line does nothing but distract from whats going on.  In fact, there are entire sections of the film I can barely remember simply due to how disconnected the music was.
4. RZA, and everything about him.  I may be unfairly bashing RZA (the actor for the main role and director responsible for this travesty), but every part of his involvement in the movie is most notably horrible.  He can't act, period. When he is attempting to deliver dialouge he can barely be understood.  The costume wardrobe he has for most of the film would be laughable if it actually felt like it was intended to be a joke (he spends about half the film walking around a beat up Chinese village dressed like Ezio from the Assassin's Creed games). His atempts at fighting are pathetic, like watching kids with a camera play power rangers. All the decisions for the film were his responsibility as the director and therefore I can aim all my disappointment squarely at him.
5. All the combat scenes are bad.  I can appreciate the Tarantino style gore, but to actually do "wire-fu" this bad in a kung fu 'parody' goes beyond deliberate and into the realm of incompetent. The film could have been justified if all else were bad so long as it actually had engaging fight scenes (the movies it's based on were like that), but this movie fails on that most important ingrediant.
6. Lastly, it feels too long.  At only 95-107 minutes (depending on which version you watch), the movie itself is not long, but it is so filled with extranious backstories, worthless side stories and explanations, and forgettable if not unhearable dialouge that the movie just grinds on forever.

Knowing that films like this can be done right (see Kung Pow: Enter the Fist and Tarantino's own Kill Bill) and that expectations for this kind of movie really shouldn't be that high, it is a total shame to see a movie like this take money that could have been used for much more worthy projects. When a movie is "presented by" Quentin Tarantino, written by the RZA and Eli Roth and stars Russell Crowe and Lucy Liu you have a right to at least expect it to resemble a professionally made film. The new would-be Wuxia epic the Man With the Iron Fists is like an amateur production ,a bastardized cross between a Shaw Brothers martial arts adventure and a feature length movie trailer. Full of hype and missed potential, this is no better than any random cheaply made direct-to-DVD movie without big names. In this case so much talent, equals so much waste.
 First time director RZA is a well known fan of classic martial arts films, his rap group the Wu Tang Clan used a great deal of wuxia imagery in their music, starting with their name. If RZA does in fact love the genre, this is a bad representation of that, treating the wuxia genre as little more than a joke, one that`s not funny either. In a post Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon-era, the desire to apologize for martial arts movies would seem to no longer be a needed defense.
 Wuxia, the current cool in thing for westerners to call the martial arts genre, in Chinese it means heroic or chivalrias martial arts stories.  Wuxia pictures have been around nearly as long as movies themselves, but only recently have they ascended to there rightful place in Western film culture. The genre is now excepted, with critically studies that have allowed the once ghettoized genre a well deserved appreciated,
 These movies share much in common with the American western, easterns if you will, and like the western many of the best folk tales told in their culture have unfold on film within this noble genre. It is also worth noting that a lot of these movies are nearly as good as the classic American westerns, especially the HK Shaw Brothers titles of the 60's and 70's and directors  such as Cheng Cheh, King Hu and Li Chuai Ling are comparable to the likes of Sam Peckinpah, John Sturges or Anthony Mann, Now we add this movie to the association, one that is not only an embarrassment, but an insult, the Man With the Iron Fists takes the accomplished merits back several decades.
 The script is ludicrous, jumbled, disoriented and rambling. Eli Roth came on board to help RZA form and finish his screenplay, I can't imagine he did a lot of  the finished work, while not a tremendous writer. Roth's work usually is far more creditable than this.
 The dialogue in the Man With the Iron Fist is excruciating, spoken with corny sincerity. This no doubt is meant to be "homage" to the old English dubbed kung fu epics of the past, now does that not sound like a mistake. It just doesn't work when the lips match up with these unspeakable lines of discourse.
 Russell Crowe adds class and credibility, which are otherwise sorely lacking. Crowe has top billing, but plays a rather thankless supporting role, but offers an occasional distraction from the rest of the frivolities. Crowe also has never looked so out of shape, with his full beard and middle age spreading he's starting to resemble Orson Welles. Just why did Crowe do this film, it's mind-boggling to think of such a talented actor and huge movie star wasting his offerings on this.
 Lucy Liu is likeably enthusiastic, but the role is under developed and she's left floundering. Part of the reason for this is that the whole movie is terribly misogynistic, the woman are all whores and are either treacherous or just merrily in the way, one character is both. Liu's presence will also no doubt make viewers recall the far superior Kill Bill.
 The rest of the cast is a liability, "WWE superstar" Dave Bautista once again shows he has no acting skills what so ever. UFC champ Cung Le is still failing at his attempts to be a movie star. Rick Yune and Jamie Chung have to little screen time to make much impact as token Asian heroes. Pam Grier, Gordon Liu and Chen Kuan-tai show up in pointless cameos that just remind you of better movies you could be watching. As an actor RZA is better than he is a director, but not noticeably so. Playing the film's title character and narrator, like his direction, RZA speaks a lot, but says little.
 Is it too much to ask for the Man With the Iron Fists  to at the very least be a fun guilty pleasure, but no such luck. The movie lacks any sort of post Tarantino-style of self aware humor, or any intentional humor at all. The film is too brutally gory for it's own good , it is also unnecessarily profane, which does not keep with the genre's traditions, but seems designed to appeal to the hip-hop crowd. It is all so predicable, terribly derivative and worst of all boring. It is a long ninety-six minutes when a martial arts movie lacks even the credibility of a Kung Fu Panda flick.
 Cheaply made and very much looking it, I have to seriously wonder if RZA's intentions were not to make a bad movie. If so, he has succeeded beyond his wildest dreams. This is not like Tarantino and Rodriguez's Grindhouse, which had a lot of fun making bad movies better. The Man With the Iron Fists manages to make good movies appear bad.
  In theory this movie should have rocked, but it does anything but. RZA proves to be a lousy writer, a half assed actor and worst no filmmaker. RZA allegedly spent some seven years trying to get this made and the original run time is said to have been four hours long, I do have to ponder if it was any more coherent, but glad I don`t have to find out.  .
 RZA does fill the movie with an effective audible soundtrack, from hip-hop numbers to Cantonese pop tunes, not to mention a nicely rousing score. The movie looks good, it's visually striking with clever editing and good photography, but lousy action sequences in a dull and unpleasant turkey. The tagline is that this puts the f.u. in kung fu, that's not clever, that's just being honest.

I'll try to break this review down to the best of my abilities.

THE GOOD:

The characters were very creative. RZA is the skilled village black smith with story narration.  Russel Crowe as Mr. Knife was quite amusing.  His weapons were neat.  Lucy Lui owns/owns a brothel, but her true identity & intentions is reveiled towards the end.  Former wrestling star David Bautista as Brass Body.  Need I say more?  Rick Yune as X-Blade, a walking swiss army knife, so to speak.  Plus a few more.

The action was incredible.  At times, over the top with its numerous graphic scenes.  If all you care about is action, this movie would be up your alley.

THE BAD:

The plot.  Though there was one, it was scattered.  Highly unorganized.

Though this movie was capturing the spirit of the kung fu genre, it really isn't a Kung Fu movie.  The fight scenes didn't really display much kung fu in my opinion. The fight scenes were over the top, but not really kung fu.  I can see where kung fu fans had a hard time with this.

The editing, how can I put this, was SLOPPY.  What little kung fu that was displayed, was stunted due to the editing.
Fast editing cuts work, if done right.  At times, it made the movie look like a complete mess.

Then there's the RZA.  If he plans to star in a movie he directs, I would hope he'd spend extra time on his choreography in the future.  His fighting, or lack there of, was a kiddy pool filled with misery.  To make it worse, they tried to hide his handicap with special effects.

I don't how well it would've done without Tarantino's name slapped on it, but all and all I did enjoy the movie.  It's worth a watch.  RZA pays his respects to Kung Fu flicks in his own vision.  I have no issues adding it to my collection.  That being said I would strongly advise you rent it before you purchase it.

The Man With the Iron Fists (2012, Universal Pictures)is a spoof of classic kung fu movies. The plot centers around a blacksmith (RZA) whose is working so he can earn enough money to leave his dangerous village. He gets wrapped up in a feud over gold between clans in the village. That's about all there is for the plot. It's pretty thin but does just enough to provide a vehicle for some great action.

And that action is what really shines in this movie. The pacing is swift, leaving very little time between action sequences. The action sequences themselves are some of the most satisfying I have seen in some time. RZA takes us back to the classic Kung Fu days with over the top, very stylized, floaty fight scenes. These scenes are enhanced by the unique weapons that various characters posses. It almost reminded me of Mortal Kombat with each character truly having different skill sets and weapons. Add in the wonderfully score also done by RZA and you get some very entertaining action scenes.

I think he may have been better off just sticking to writing, directing, and scoring the movie.

I mean some of the other music was just wrong for the scenes they were placed in. I expected more than this from RZA.

I've never written a review, but it's high time for me to come out from the anonymous shadows of the internet and put my money where my mouth is. First and foremost, as if the star rating didn't give it away, I found this movie very enjoyable. However, I'm writing this review today not as praise for all its rights, but as a defense for all its wrongs. Many of the reviews I've read find the movie bland, flat, and without flare. However, given the genre it's heavily persuaded by, the American 70's kung-fu theater, this is an out and out homage to that time period and culture. The dialogue has been cited as "terrible", but honestly, who watched kung-fu movies for the dialogue? Yes, it sets the story and yes, it advances the plot, but generally most people are there to watch people beat the snot out of each other. Personally, I found the writing fine, but that's not what this review is about.

Another personal favorite of the less than positive reviews is pointing out the unimaginative scenery and characters. Jungle Village. Brass Body. However, again, this is a tribute to the kung-fu theater of yesteryear. Most of the poorly dubbed movies of that era suffered from extremely simple translations and thus had direct, to the point naming conventions. This is also why, as stated in the previous paragraph, the dialogue comes off as flat, or even overly acted with no substance. Again, a call back to the cinematic era it's referencing. To be honest, though, most Asian languages are very direct in their naming. For instance, Japan in Japanese is "Nihon", with "Ni" meaning sun and "hon" meaning source, so Japan, land of the rising sun. Get it?

Now, I've only seen a few references to this next particular issue, but I feel it must be addressed, and that is the soundtrack. Some have said the hip hop seems out of place and my only retort would be, "Have any of you seen Samurai Champloo?" That is a quintessential example of the perfect harmony between hip hop and the ancient Asian culture and I believe it works here as well.

I could go on and on, but I'm sure many of you have stopped reading or simply made up your own mind long ago and I wouldn't be able to sway you otherwise. However, for those that have trudged along this far, I implore you to watch this film with an open mind and a laid back attitude, appreciating for what it is: a homage to a simpler time in theater. This isn't a 13 Assassins or a Hero or a Zatoichi, this is a man professing his love to a cinema that he is so fond of. I tip my hat to thee, RZA.

The Man with the Iron Fists(released Nov/12)stars,among others,RZA,the blacksmith Thaddeus,Rick Yune as Zen-Yi,X-Blade,Russell Crowe as Jack Knife,Lucy Liu as Madam Blossom,David Bautista as Brass Body,Jamie Chung as Lady Silk,Cung Le as Bronze Lion,and Byron Mann as Silver Lion. This film is a throwback to the 60s and 70s Hong Kong films that have inspired many producers,directors and actors over the years. Those films were originally for the most part fantasies,some serious others not. Some could even be considered Chinese westerns. They made big stars out of many of the actors in their home countries. What we in North America saw was oft times poor,faded prints with horrible dubbings into English. They became a joke and the plots,to us,were mostly forgettable. They have been lampooned consistently over the years since. This film plays it all very straight but uses the same style as those old Hong Kong pictures. Unfortunately the story is as lame as any of the poorest Hong Kong films and drags interminably to the end.
The story finds the setting in China,in a time of feuding clans. The emperor has a shipment of gold traveling across the country and the head of the lion clan intends to protect it for him. However two of his underlings kill him and take over,and they scheme to steal the gold. Thrown into this mix is the son of the slain leader,X Blade,Jack Knife a mercenary British soldier who,with X Blade,converge on Jungle Town and meet up with a black,blacksmith,whose specialty is forging weapons of the finest calibre.
Since the lion clan is no longer in the picture the governor sends the Gemini squad to protect the gold. They arrive in the town with it and hunker down in the hotel/brothel run by Madam Blossom. The lion clan kill the Gemini`s and commandeer the gold. They also sever the blacksmiths arms,who ends up forging iron fists onto his stumps. He teams with Jack Knife and X Blade to try and take down the lion clan. The clan makes a deal with the madam,who has the gold in storage beneath the brothel. She knows its a promise they will never keep so she strikes back first by killing almost all of its members the night before they are to leave.
Arriving outside the city a platoon of well armed soldiers sent by the Emperor enters the town and are paused outside the brothel and ready to level it if the gold is not forthcoming. The three fight and defeat their enemies and Jack Knife,in the nick of time,appears to stop the soldiers from firing. The film ends as all three go their separate ways. In an epilogue X Blade`s wife is kidnapped by members of a bird clan and he must rescue her. He returns to the blacksmith for help.
As in the old Hong Kong films the fights usually don`t take much time to break out and this film is no different. It also uses those,now,cheesy stunts and close ups of faces distorted in rage to propel things along,like the old Hong Kong-ers(the memories just come flooding back!).When the fights resume in earnest near the end of the film at the climax,they now use a more modern style to stage them,with quick camera movement,action freezing and the like. In between we have this long and drawn out plot as each character and group are introduced. We even get back stories on some of the characters. One such borefest is the backdrop to the blacksmith`s story. As if things weren`t going slowly enough,they had to insert that story to slow things almost to a halt. If this film had been sending the entire Hong Kong genre up,or was doing it in a visually stylistic interpretation ala Crouching Tiger,Hidden Dragon,this film may have stood some chance of being half decent. As it is,to actually have the nerve to play this thing ``straight``,is to commit filmic suicide. Sorry Mr. Diggs,this is bad.
Technically speaking the film is in its w/s a/r of 2:40:1 and is clear and crisp. Extras include deleted scenes and some featurettes. This disc also contains the theatrical AND the extended versions.
All in all a film that falls totally flat and into its Hong Kong rice bowl. If you,like I,were expecting a bit of imaginative tricks and style ala Crouching Tiger,Hidden Dragon,then think again. Just because it has Tarantino`s name attached,doesn`t mean it is on Tarantino`s level.

I'm a huge fan of the old time kung fu movies. When I saw the trailer for Man With The Iron Fists it looked like a movie tailor made for me. Boy was I wrong.

I watched the first half of the movie before growing bored and wandering out of theater. During the many hours I spent watching the first half - or at least it seemed that long - I saw absolutely nothing to indicate that any actor or stunt-man appearing in the movie had ever had a martial arts lesson. Seriously, the fight choreography looked like what a bunch of school boys, with absolutely no martial arts background, might put together trying to copy what they saw in Kung fu Theater. Maybe there was some martial arts in the 2nd half of the movie, I didn't make it that far. I later learned that there were a couple real martial artists in this movie. Based on what I saw on the screen, I never would have figured that out.

What Iron Fist did have, in abundance, was lots and lots of bright red fluid. I couldn't begin to tell you how many limbs were severed in the first 15 minutes. There was one scene where one "martial artist" rips the arms off another "martial artist" using something that was possibly some kind of tiger style. There was a guy in a suit full of switchblades that does a lot of jumping and spinning and severing of arteries. There's also Russell Crowe who seems to know even less about fighting than the uncoordinated "martial artists." But he has a pair of scissors with a pistol grip that he uses to disembowel his clumsy opponents.

The sets and cinematography were first rate, impressive but not impressive enough to make up for the terrible writing, directing and fight choreography. The costumes looked like a lot of thought and a lot of money had gone into them. Iron Fist had a $20 million budget, and was shot in China where that kind of money will go pretty far. It's a shame that RZA didn't spring for a first rate choreographer. But it's also a shame that the movie wasn't better written and directed. The real shame of it is that all the ingredient to make a good kung fu movie were in place, the only thing missing was a recipe and someone who knew how to mix them.

If you're a fan of simulated blood, simulated amputations and simulated disembowelments - and couldn't care less if anyone on the screen could actually kick their way out of a paper bag - this is the movie for you. If you want to see some actual martial artists with real skill and real choreography, get yourself some Shaw Brothers kung fu DVDs and skip watching this steaming pile.

Addison Smith (RZA) is a blacksmith in an anachronistic 19th century medieval Oriental village. His plan is to leave the area with his prostitute girlfriend Lady Silk (Jamie Chung) to whom he gives his money to put away for when they escape. There are two villages/ clans that are in battle with each other, the Lions and the Wolves who come complete with their own puns. The emperor asks the head of the Lions, Gold Lion (Kuan Tai Chen) to take a shipment of gold to a northern village as some sort of peace offering (plot isn't important in this film). He is betrayed and killed by his two deputies, Silver and Bronze Lion. I think you see where this naming thing is going...move over James Bond.

Zen Yi, The X-Blade (Rick Yune) decides to avenge his father's death while Silver Lion has declared war on the Wolf Clan and the Geminis escort the gold. To add to the confusion, Silver Lion has hired the impenetrable Brass Body (Dave Bautista) to hunt Zen Yi while Jack Knife (Russell Crowe) a British killer fortune seeker hangs out at the very colorful brothel called the Pink Blossom run by Madam Blossom (Lucy Liu).

This film includes a modern hip-hop sound track complete with MF and N words. The martial arts fighting ignores the laws of gravity. The blood squirts are over the top bright red. Zen Yi has spring loaded 8 inch spikes that pop out of 2 inches of armor. The fighting is extremely choreographed. Of course there is the signature Tarantino restaurant scene and split screen. No weird flashbacks. RZA didn't copy that. Worth a view for "Kill Bill" fans.

Parental Guide: F-bombs, N-word, sex, no nudity.

The Man With the Iron Fists is a movie that was 'presented' (not produced) by Quentin Tarantino and directed by RZA. It centers on the story of a black blacksmith in China, who is trying to leave his hostile home village that's entrenched in between good ol' clan wars.

If you are seeking to be entertained, look no further. RZA blends the 'hip-hop samurai' type of music and feel -- prevalent in a lot of anime in recent years -- with the Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon-floating-around-style of fighting to create a high-flying (no pun intended) and adventurous parody of the genres with a Spaguetti Western flare. Needless to say, visually this movie is great in many respects.

However, beyond that, the movie suffers from more than a few noticeable stumbling points. The first being dialogue. Not only is the writing over-simplified, but the fact that some of the Chinese characters have Oriental-English accents while others speak perfectly clear English is something that will distract some viewers from the already simple plot. In addition, the main antagonist Silver Lion is portrayed as the funny one-liner villain, but there are times when his role feels overdone and out of place during the more serious scenes. Perhaps this harkens back to the older Kung-fu movie time other reviewers mentioned, but for me it was distracting.

Another caveat is the characters. They didn't feel very memorable, which is again probably due to the dialogue. The exception here is Russel Crowe's character, who exhibits wit, style, and the fact he sticks out like a sore thumb in a charming way. While I feel he did an extraordinary job in executing this role, I'm not exactly sure how his career will be affected in the long-run from this... You'll know what I mean.

Lastly, there were gaps in terms of the suspension of belief. While these types of movies are going to exhibit combat and visuals that are uncanny, a few of the developments toward the end, including one bad guy in particular, just felt like huge leaps of faith without any sort of explanation at all. I don't want to spoil anything, but again I think you'll know what I mean as you watch.

Now before I sound overly critical, let me tip my hat off to RZA. Not only did he direct the movie. He wrote it, helped compose the soundtrack, and starred as the blacksmith. This truly is RZA's movie in every sense of the phrase.

With so many responsibilities on one person, I can't help but critique this movie with admiration for it. It may not be on the Tarantino level, but if this is a beginning path for RZA I am excited to see what he comes up with next. Watch TMWTIF with the right expectations. If you're expecting Kill Bill or Pulp Fiction, take it down a good notch. If you're expecting a parody of exaggerated, oriental combat and hip-hop anime with Spaghuetti Western tropes, you're in for an entertaining ride. It's worth a watch, even if it doesn't etch itself into your soul.

The premise is thin, the action hits hard and fast, and it's completely popcornworthy. That said, I found it odd that accomplished actors like Lucy Liu and Russell Crowe appeared in this flick, but I guess everyone has bills to pay or a few days that you just don't want to take seriously. So, here's the story. It's classical China. A shipment of gold is being sent to the hinterlands (cue the spaghetti western music). The Lion Clan, who mostly seem to have haircuts like Jareth from Labyrinth, have an internal power shift and decide the gold is theirs. A brave few stand against the bullies and (no suprise here) win the day. Throw in some wildly improbable weapons, remarkable gymnastics, and a pocketful of anachronisms, and you've pretty much got it. (Were those cuties of negotiable affection really wearing fishnets and hotpants in classical China?) Given the general inanity, it shouldn't have annoyed me the three non-Asians in the flick had three of the four leading roles - of course, Liu filled that out. As in so many movies from Shangri-La on, and even before that, the Asian majority consisted largely of spear-carriers (figuratively or not), and even Liu wasn't really one of the good guys. Well, at least there was one black among non-Asians: RZA who (incidentally) not only starred but wrote and directed as well. Don't get your hopes up, and it's sure to exceed them. -- wiredweird

fantastic movie! i saw a lot of very unique and fun kung fu ideas that could only come from a true movie fan such as the rza! there is a brass statue of a man that is in many movies as a training dummy for qi (chi) blocking attacks. in this movie there is the statue and a man with skin that can become brass at will, it links up toward the end in such a cool way i was blown away. i imagine the rza back in the 70's thinking "what if someone had to fight the qi training statue? then they would be really f*&%ed!"

i could see where he deliberately paid homage to old kung fu films with some of the camera work, hair and acting styles, this kind of thing might look odd too someone who hasn't seen older kung fu movies as some of it seems corny or stilted (which is how those old movies are, something fans love!). but even so, they would get over it every time one of the AMAZING battles started.

at first the rap music came off as out of place. this is coming from a wu tang clan fan since the 36 chambers, and digital bullet is one of my favorite albums, but they're in ancient china and it's all hip hop style which doesn't really match up, but it grew on me very fast and by the end i was bobbing my head to the beats and enjoying them with the fight scenes. i grew up listening to wu tang, and rza always puts cuts from classic kung fu movies in his music. it's really cool hearing them and then, years later, stumbling over the same lines or music while watching the movie they're from without knowing it ahead of time. it's like: "why do i recognize this? i've never seen this movie... oh yeah! wu tang!" this was the exact opposite of that and it worked pretty well! i'm watching a kung fu movie and thinking "wait a minute, i know that song!"

and the story? phenomenal! really fun stuff going on and lots of surprises. russel crow is a riot in this movie. i was thoroughly entertained. i love buddhism, kung fu, and i dig the rza's music so the scene at the buddhist temple had me smiling from ear to ear.
